content.raw:
Can you:

* cache the list of callbacks (this can, and probably should be, a lazy cache so that if we turn the analysis submission into a plugin, we don't have to resolve plugin instantiation order dependencies! So populate a list the first time it runs through your current code and then use that list of callbacks after that)  
* Rename the callback to something more descriptive (I'm having a hard time coming up with something nice, but maybe `analysis_cancel_send`? I would probably also recommend that the local variable `analysis_filter` is renamed to `send_to_analysis` and has it's logic inverted to match the new name. This just makes the code slightly quicker to understand for people who will look at it in the future.
content.html:
Can you:

  • cache the list of callbacks (this can, and probably should be, a lazy cache so that if we turn the analysis submission into a plugin, we don't have to resolve plugin instantiation order dependencies! So populate a list the first time it runs through your current code and then use that list of callbacks after that)
  • Rename the callback to something more descriptive (I'm having a hard time coming up with something nice, but maybe analysis_cancel_send? I would probably also recommend that the local variable analysis_filter is renamed to send_to_analysis and has it's logic inverted to match the new name. This just makes the code slightly quicker to understand for people who will look at it in the future.

content.raw:
Caching callbacks makes sense. We should maybe create the list of callbacks at plugin initialization in `__main__.py` and then send it to queue manager?

I though analysis\_filter was descriptive as it filters files from analysis. Would `block_analysis_submission` be better? Changing the local variable to `send_to_analysis` with inverted behavior makes sense will change that.
content.html:
Caching callbacks makes sense. We should maybe create the list of callbacks at plugin initialization in __main__.py and then send it to queue manager?

I though analysis_filter was descriptive as it filters files from analysis. Would block_analysis_submission be better? Changing the local variable to send_to_analysis with inverted behavior makes sense will change that.

content.raw: I renamed the variables. I also added a function to get callbacks by name. This function has a cache that can be rebuild by keyword argument.
content.html: I renamed the variables. I also added a function to get callbacks by name. This function has a cache that can be rebuild by keyword argument.

content.raw:
Sorry for the delay in reviewing this.....Some more adjustments. Could you:

1. decorate `get_callbacks()` with `@inmain_decorator(True)` so that it runs in the main thread \(protects against race conditions in the future if we expand the use of the callbacks. I also don't know whether we consider anything to do with accessing plugins to be thread safe, so let's err on the side of caution\)
2. Wrap the `for` loop in `get_callbacks()` inside a try-except block \(and log to `self._logger` in the exception which is the logger that exists in the main thread\) just in case something breaks when getting plugins from BLACS or asking the plugin for the callbacks.

Then I think we're good to merge
content.html:
Sorry for the delay in reviewing this.....Some more adjustments. Could you:

  1. decorate get_callbacks() with @inmain_decorator(True) so that it runs in the main thread (protects against race conditions in the future if we expand the use of the callbacks. I also don't know whether we consider anything to do with accessing plugins to be thread safe, so let's err on the side of caution)
  2. Wrap the for loop in get_callbacks() inside a try-except block (and log to self._logger in the exception which is the logger that exists in the main thread) just in case something breaks when getting plugins from BLACS or asking the plugin for the callbacks.

Then I think we're good to merge

content.raw: Cool! FYI, the logger module has a method `exception` which automatically puts the traceback in the message. I'll swap it over myself after merging.
content.html: Cool! FYI, the logger module has a method exception which automatically puts the traceback in the message. I'll swap it over myself after merging.
